content:
Quick Reference Mapping rule: $(x, y) \rightarrow (\frac{x}{b}+h)(ay+k)$ Transformations for a function: $y=af(b(x-h))+k$ (or $y=af(k(x-h))+c$ )
Transformations: For this equation, $y=af(b(x-h))+k$ :
 Vertical Scaling (using $a$)  If $|a| > 1$: vs by $a$. Else if $0 < |a| < 1$: vc by $a$.   Vertical Reflection (using $a$)  If $a < 0$: reflect on x-axis.   Horizontal Scaling (using $b$)  If $|b| > 1$: hs by $b$. Else if $0 < |b| < 1$: hc by $b$.   Horizontal Reflection (using $b$)  If $b < 0$: reflect on y-axis.   Horizontal Translation (using $h$)  If $h > 0$: ht $h$ right. Else uf $h < 0$: ht $h$ left.   Horizontal Translation (using $k$)  If $k > 0$: vt $k$ up. Else uf $k < 0$: vt $k$ down.    NOTE: Sets (e.g. domain and range) do not have repeats (e.g. $\{1, 2\}$ ).
NOTE: expand the macro/function as well when doing the equation (i.e. $y=|x+2|$ not $g(x)=|x|, y=g(x+2)$ )
Lesson 1: Relations and Functions Let $x$, $y$ represent an independent, and dependent variable, respectively.
A relation defines relations between two sets.
It can also be represented as a set of ordered pairs with two values, $x$ and $y$.
It can also be defined as a referentially transparent and side-effect-free procedure (in computer science).
Relation = List[Tuple[complex, complex]]
A function is a relation where each value of $x$ corresponds with only one value of $y$.
The domain of a relation is the set of all values of $x$.
def domain(relation): return [s[0] for s in relation] The range of a relation is the set of all values of $y$.
def range(relation): return [s[1] for s in relation] Set Notation  ${…}$ defines a set. $(…)$ defines a tuple. $D{…}$ defines the domain of a set. $R{…}$ defines the range of a set.  Example  For a relation $S{(0, 1), (2, 3), (4, 5)}$, $D_S{0, 2, 4}$, and $R_S{1, 3, 5}$. This relation is a function. For a relation $S{(0, 1), (2, 1), (4, 5)}$, $D_S{0, 2, 4}$, and $R_S{1, 1, 5}$.s This relation is not a function ($S(0) = S(2)$).  Interval Notation Note: using the definition in ISO 80000-2:2019.
 $($ and $)$ are exclusive endpoints (the empty circle in number lines) $[$ and $]$ are inclusive endpoints (the filled circle in number lines)  Therefore: $$ \begin{align} {\color{Maroon}(} a,b{\color{Maroon})} = \mathopen{\color{Maroon}]}a,b\mathclose{\color{Maroon}[} &= \{x\in\mathbb{R}\mid a{\color{Maroon}{}The above fenced code block and its content is from Interval (mathematics) — Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia (by Wikipedia contributors).
Vertical Line Test The vertical line test can be used to determine whether a relation is a function. If for every vertical line on the appropriate plane, there exists only one point where the vertical line intersects the relation, the relation is a function.
An example of a relation:
 circle a circle centred at the origin, which fails the vertical line test because a vertical line at x=0 goes through two points         Figure with identifier circ : circle a circle centred at the origin, which fails the vertical line test because a vertical line at x=0 goes through two points
  An example of a function:
 linear a linear equation, which fails the vertical line test because a vertical line at x=0 goes through two points         Figure with identifier lin : linear a linear equation, which fails the vertical line test because a vertical line at x=0 goes through two points
  An example of a function:
 quadratic an quadratic equation, which fails the vertical line test because a vertical line at x=0 goes through two points         Figure with identifier quad : quadratic an quadratic equation, which fails the vertical line test because a vertical line at x=0 goes through two points
  An example of a relation:
 inverse quadratic an inverse quadratic equation, which fails the vertical line test because a vertical line at x=0 goes through two points         Figure with identifier inv-quad : inverse quadratic an inverse quadratic equation, which fails the vertical line test because a vertical line at x=0 goes through two points
  Ensuring a Relation is a Function To ensure a relation is a function, restrict its domain to make sure that all conflicts are resolved.
For example, for this relation:
 a relation         Figure with identifier restrict-rel : a relation   we can restrict the domain: $D{x\in \mathbb{R} | x \ge 0}$
 a relation         Figure with identifier restrict-fn : a relation   Lesson 2: Function Notation $f(x)$ is pronounced as “f of x”, “f at x”, among many others. It means to replace $f(x)$ with the definition of $f(x)$.
For example, if $f(x)=x+1$, $f(1) = 1+1 = 2$ and $f(y) = x+y$.
 a function a function for use in the example below         Figure with identifier func : a function a function for use in the example below
  $f(0) = 0$
Composition of Functions Function composition is a useful way to make new functions. It is done using the $\circ$ operator.
$(f\circ g)(x) = f(g(x))$
This is pronounced as “f composed with g of x” ($g\circ f$ is pronounced “g composed with f”).
Note that this is similar to the funtion composition operator (.) in Haskell: (f . g)(x) = f(g(x))
For example, if $g(x)=5x^2+1$, and $f(x)=x+1$, then $g(f(x)) = (g\circ f)(x) = g(x+1) = 5(x+1)^2+1$
Lesson 3: Properties of Parent Functions Even functions satisfy $f(x) = f(-x)$. (notice how even functions have even exponents (i.e. $\frac{n}{2} \in \mathbb{Z}$ in $y=x^n+c$)) For example, $y = |x|$ is even, and therefore it is symmetric on the y axis:  an even function          Figure with identifier even-func : an even function   For example, $f$ is even, where $f(x) = -x^2-2x^2+4$, since $f(-x) = -(-x)^2-2(-x)^2+4 = -x^2+2x^2+4 = f(x)$.
Odd functions (奇関数) satisfy $f(x) = -f(-x)$. For example, $y = x$ is odd, and therefore it is mirrored on both the $x$ and $y$ axes.  an even function          Figure with identifier odd-func : an even function   For example, $f$ is odd, where $f(x) = x^3+4x$, since $-f(-x) = -((-x)^3+4(-x)) = -(-x^3-4x) = x^3+4x = f(x)$.
Functions that are neither even or odd do not meet any of the requirements.
For example, $f$ is neither, where $f(x)=\sqrt{x}$, since $-f(-x) = -(\sqrt{-x}) = -\sqrt{-x} \ne f(x)$, and since $f(-x) = \sqrt{-x} \ne f(x)$.
TODO: diagram An asymptote is a line that the graph of a relation gets closer to, but never meets
TODO: diagram Increasing and Decreasing Functions (possibly non-standard) Increasing functions (増加関数) are functions where $y$ always increases when $x$ increases. In other words, the slope is always $\ge 0$. Another way to put it is that the derivative of the function never goes below 0.
 an even function         Figure with identifier incr-func : an even function   Decreasing functions (減少関数) are the oppoosite of increasing functions: They are functions where $y$ always decreases when $x$ increases. In other words, the slope is always $\le 0$. Another way to put it is that the derivative of the function never goes above 0.
 an even function          Figure with identifier decr-func : an even function      Name Equation Graph Domain Range Symmetry Asymptotes $x$ Intercept $y$ Intercept Quadrants Increasing     Constant Function $f(x)=c$ TODO $D{x\in \mathbb{R}}$ $R{y\in \mathbb{R} where y=c}$ Even None None or all $c$ I and II Constant   Linear Function $f(x)=x$ TODO $D{x\in \mathbb{R}}$ $R{y\in \mathbb{R}}$ Odd None 0 0 I and III Increasing   Quadratic Function $f(x)=x^2$ TODO $D{x\in \mathbb{R}}$ $R{y\in \mathbb{R} where y \ge 0}$ Even None 0 0 I and II Neither   Cubic Function $f(x)=x^3$ TODO $D{x\in \mathbb{R}}$ $R{y\in \mathbb{R}}$ Odd None 0 0 I and III Increasing   Root Function $f(x)=\sqrt{x}$ TODO $D{x\in \mathbb{R} where x \ge 0}$ $R{y\in \mathbb{R} where y \ge 0}$ Neither None 0 0 I Increasing   Reciprocal Function $f(x)=\frac{1}{x}$ TODO $D{x\in \mathbb{R} where x \ne 0}$ $R{y\in \mathbb{R} where y \ne 0}$ Odd $x=0$ and $y=0$ None None I and III Decreasing   Absolute Function $f(x)=abs(x)$ TODO $D{x\in \mathbb{R} where x \ne 0}$ $R{y\in \mathbb{R} where y \ne 0}$ Odd $x=0$ and $y=0$ None None I and III Decreasing    TODO chart Lesson 4: Getting the Domain and Range of a Function For any function, get the parent function and put it into the following form: $$g(x)=af(k(x-d))+c$$
Each parent function ($f(x)$) has the domain and range. To get the domain and range of the function ($g(x)$), substitute the $x$ in the domain and the $y$ in the range to $x-d$ and $y-c$.
For example, to get the domain and range of $(x)$, where $f(x)=\sqrt{x}$, and where $g(x)=\sqrt{x-3}=af(k(x-d))+c$, substitute $x-d$ for $x$ and $y-c$ for $y$: $$d=3, d\in \mathbb{R}, x-d=x-3$$ $$c=0, y-c=y, c\in \mathbb{R}$$ $$D\{x+d\in \mathbb{R} | x-d\ge 0\}$$ $$D\{x\in \mathbb{R} | x\ge 3\}$$ $$R\{y+c\in \mathbb{R} | y-c\ge 0\}$$ $$R\{y\in \mathbb{R} | y\ge 0\}$$ Lesson 5: Absolute Values and Inequalities The absolute value of a value is the distance from 0 on the number line. Since distances are always positive: $|x|\in \{0, \mathbb{Z}\}$ To solve abosolute values, split $|x|$ to $-x$ and $+x$.
$$|2x+3|\le 4$$ $$2x+3\le 4, -2x-3\le 4$$ $$2x\le 1, -2x\le 7$$ $$x\le \frac{1}{2}, x\ge \frac{-7}{2}$$ $$\frac{-7}{2}\le x\le \frac{1}{2}$$ Inequalities When both sides of an inequality are multiplied or divided by a negative number, it is “reversed”. $$a\lt b$$ $$x\le y$$ $$-a\gt -b$$ $$-x\ge -y$$ For example, to solve $3x-2\le 2x+1$ and sketch it on the number line:
$$3x-2\le 2x+1$$ $$x\le 3$$  an even function          3   Figure with identifier ineq-nl : an even function   Lesson 5: Inverses of Functions The inverse of a function reverses the operation that the function does.
For example, if $f(x)=x^2$ then $f^{-1}(x)=x^{\frac{1}{2}}$ and therefore $f(f^{-1}(x))=x$.
To determine the inverse of a function, reverse the uses of $x$ and $y$.
$$f(x)=y=2x^3+4$$ (flip $x$ and $y$)
$$f^{-1}(x)=(\frac{x-4}{2})^\frac{1}{3}$$ Resources  https://www.georgebrown.ca/sites/default/files/uploadedfiles/tlc/_documents/graphing_functions_using_transformations.pdf (archive) https://www.sydney.edu.au/content/dam/students/documents/mathematics-learning-centre/functions-and-graphs.pdf (archive)
title: Unit 8

content:
Lesson 3: Midpoints A midpoint is a point that is equiditant from two points at the end of a line segment.
$M_{AB}=(\frac{x_1+x_2}{2}, \frac{x_1+x_2}{2})$ where $A(x_1, y_1)$ and $B(x_2, y_2)$
Bisecting lines share their midpoints. For example, in parallelograms, the diagonals bisect each other.
A right bisector is a line that bisects another line and intersects it by a $90°$ angle.
M A B  Lesson 4: Length of Line Segments The distance formula can be used to calculate the length of a line segment on the Euclidean plane.
To get the length of a line segment $\overline{\rm AB}$ $A(x_1, y_1)$ $B(x_1, y_1)$
$d=\sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2+(y_2-y_1)^2}$ or $d=\frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}$
d A B  Lesson 5: Application of Formulas To get whether a triangle is a right triangle, you can get the slopes of the three sides and see if there is a pair that is reciprocal to each other (i.e. $x=\frac{-1}{y}$).
Lesson 6: Circles! The equation of a circle with:
 radius $r$ centre $O=(h, k)$ a right-top point $(x, y)$ is $(x-h)^2+(y-k)^2=r$.  Other forms of this equation include $r^2=x^2+y^2$ (notice how it’s similar to the Pythagorean theorem).
To see whether a point $A$ is inside a circle, calculate $d_{AO}$ where $O=(h, k)$.
For example, $P(-5, 9)$ is outside the circle with $r=100$:
 $d_{PO} = \sqrt{5^2+9^2} \approx 10.3$ $d_{PO} > r$ $10.3 \gtrapprox 100$  r O O
title: Unit 1

content:
Lesson 1: Properties of Triangles Circumcentre The circumcentre is the intersection of all of the perpendicular bisectors of the sides of a triangle.
 It is equidistant from the vertices inside in acute triangles outside in obtuse triangles on $M_c$ where $c$ is the hypotenuse in right triangles  To get the circumcentre of a triangle, get the bisectors of two sides and solve the linear equations of them.
For example, to get the circumcentre of a triangle with vertices $A(2, -3)$ $B(8, -2)$ $C(8, 6)$
$$M_{AC}=(5, -2.5)$$ $$m_{AC}=\frac{1}{6}$$ $$\frac{-1}{m_{AC}}=6$$ $$N=M_{CD}=(8, 2)$$ $$m_{CD}=not exist$$ $$\frac{-1}{m_{CD}}=0$$ $$2=6x+27.5$$ $$x=-17/4$$ $$y=2$$ $$(\frac{-17}{4}, 2)$$
Centroid The centroid is the intersection of all medians of a triangle.
 Inside the triangle Each median divides the triangle into two smaller triangles of equal area The centroid divides medians into segments whose length have the same ratio as $2:1$  Orthocentre The orthocentre is the intersection of the altitudes of a triangle
 inside in acute triangles outside in obtuse triangles on $B$ where $\angle B = 90°$ in right triangles  Incentre The incentre is a point at equal distance from the line segments.
 It doesn’t lie on the Euler line  Others  The altitude is the height of a shape. In other words, it is the shortest distance of a line segment from a point to the opposite side. Concurrent means that points are meeting at a single point.
title: Unit 2
